title.narrative: Practice for Change

description.narrative: The overall objective of this programme is to address the barriers that stand in the way of improving productivity and entrepreneurship, as well as participation of and benefits for society, such as the inclusion of women, girls and youth, land use change and other landscape issues at scale, among others. In summary, these are: -A culture of compliance instead of a culture that stimulates continual improvement, leading to a misuse of data, degradation of label values, and delay in the anticipated trickle down effects. This leads to exclusion of producers and further marginalization of the tough to reach, and tough to address issues. -Limited access to transformative knowledge and data to produce a business case, leading to limited access to finance, and prohibiting investment in social and environmental remediation measures for equipment and inputs. -Limited employment opportunities and lack of (business) opportunities for smallholder entrepreneurs, leading to the young generation moving to the city or abroad, and lack of real upscaling.

This programme aims is to explore, test and prove new concepts to overcome the barriers for impact in areas currently not addressed at scale: productivity and entrepreneurship, equal participation of and benefits for women and youth, land use change and other landscape issues (water, biodiversity). In partnership with private and public actors, on three different levels – production site (farm, mine or factory), national and global – we can identify barriers, develop approaches to scale up solutions, build alliances to finance the proof of concept and find venues to communicate and disseminate the proven concepts. Through our partnerships, we aim to provide proof of concept to producers, producer country governments, companies and major development programmes. We will consider this programme to be successful when we see these concepts being copied and scaled up.
producers, producer country governments, miners, companies
